revision:
Introduction to zeros of a polynomial

  1. If p(x) is a polynomial in x, then the highest power of x in p(x) is called the degree of the polynomial p(x).
  2. A polynomial of degree 1 is called a linear polynomial.
  3. A polynomial of degree 2 is called a quadratic polynomial and a polynomial of degree 3 is called a cubic polynomial.
  4. A real number k is said to be a zero of a polynomial p(x), if p(k) = 0.
  5. For a linear polynomial ax + b, a\(\neq \)0, the graph of y = ax + b is a straight line which intersects the x-axis at exactly one point, x \(=\frac {-b}a\).
  6. \(y = ax^2 + bx + c\) has one of the two shapes(parabola), open upwards for \(a\) < 0 and open downwards for \(a\) > 0 .
  7. A polynomial p(x) of degree \(n\) has at most \(n\) zeroes.
  8. The number of zeroes is \(n\) if the graph intersects the x-axis at \(n\) number of points.
